awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Control theoretic approaches for dynamic and privacy preserving distributed optimization algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Networked systems have undergone advances toward providing efficient solutions to many challenging problems in the modern world. Smart grid operations, smart transportation, and smart healthcare are just a few such networked operations that are envisioned to help us manage our resources efficiently using smarter interactions among their subsystems. However, optimally benefiting from these networked systems will require efficient operational algorithms, many of which involve in-network static or dynamic optimal decision-making. Effective solutions for such algorithms need to be distributed and implementable within the limitations inherent in communication devices. Furthermore, in many applications, these solutions also must have transparent privacy preservation properties to make them acceptable for everyday use. This proposal's research objective is to investigate how automatic control-theoretic tools can be used to develop and analyze distributed dynamic optimization algorithms that respect the restrictions inherent to communication channels and address concerns regarding privacy preservation of participating agents in smart network operation. The results of this research will facilitate the realization and adoption of optimal in-network solutions in many important cyber-physical applications, such as smart grid, sensor networks, and distributed data regression in the healthcare and banking sectors. This project research will be complemented by a multi-tiered educational, mentoring, and outreach plan to train and motivate the next generation of experts who will solve problems that will emerge  along with the new paradigms of smart networked systems. The research will be integrated into the University of California, Irvine curriculum through three main avenues: (1) developing new graduate and undergraduate courses, (2) involving students in the PI's Cooperative Systems Lab, and (3) mentoring efforts at the college and high school levels.

This project will significantly expand the current state of knowledge on distributed solutions for in-network dynamic optimization algorithm design in three separate directions: design techniques, efficient communication, and transparent privacy preservation characteristics. In terms of design techniques, the proposal will showcase a systematic distributed algorithm design using two time-scale dynamical system concepts from singular perturbation theory. For a robust, active, and smarter communication strategy, event-triggered communication approaches will be used to enable each agent to locally decide when it is necessary to communicate in order to preserve the algorithm's integrity. Finally, to achieve transparent privacy preservation, this project will include development of observability tests to identify a knowledge set that enables eavesdroppers to construct the private data of other agents in the network using sophisticated observers, such as neuro-observers. The project will also include design of solutions for resistance of these intrusions by developing tools and methods to create augmentations that induce privacy preservation in distributed dynamic optimization algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
Recent technological advancements in computing and communication networks have enabled a new paradigm of distributed operations across various sectors, including transportation systems, smart grids, and autonomous multi-robotic systems. In these new platforms, modular components work collaboratively to achieve global objectives extending the range of system capabilities. The optimal functioning of these large-scale networked modular systems requires a novel set of optimization algorithms. These algorithms enable components to perform local calculations based on their specific objectives and data while coordinating with neighboring entities to achieve optimal resource allocation or other optimal decision-making objectives for the entire system. To fully harness the potential of these networked systems, it is essential to develop efficient optimization algorithms that support both static and dynamic in-network decision-making. These algorithms must be distributed, operate within the constraints of communication devices, and ensure transparent privacy preservation to be widely accepted in everyday applications. The premise of this project was employing control-theoretic tools to develop such distributed optimization algorithms. Furthermore, the project expanded into a collaborative effort with Indian partners, supported by supplemental funding as part of a US-Indo collaboration program, to apply these algorithms to real-time monitoring and resource-aware deployment of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in open-cast mining environments.

On the intellectual merit side, project outcomes included the development of an understanding of analyzing consensus algorithms and the optimization algorithms themselves as pseudo-dynamical systems, leveraging approaches known and fully understood in the dynamics and control community for physical dynamical systems. (a) We showed how static and dynamic consensus algorithms, which are the building blocks of gradient tracking distributed optimization algorithms, can be accelerated using delayed inter-neighbor agreement feedback. This approach was inspired by theoretical knowledge of acceleration through delayed feedback in dynamical systems.(b) We demonstrated how various distributed optimal resource allocation algorithms can be constructed systematically using the notion of two-time scale systems known in small perturbation theory for dynamical systems. (c) We designed a suite of distributed dynamic optimization algorithms that operate efficiently under time-varying cost functions. Our algorithms leverage control-theoretic approaches to relax existing limitations, such as the need for uniform Hessians across the network. (d) For dynamic optimization problems, we also studied the design of first-order algorithms and showed rigorously the value of using temporal information about the cost in improving the tracking performance, and how this information is the distinguishing factor between time-varying optimization and the more well-known online optimization. (e) We developed novel approaches to preserve privacy in average consensus and distributed optimization algorithms. Unlike traditional approaches, such as differential privacy that focus on introducing a `fudge factor' using added noise, which leaves the door open to gaining an estimate of the private information, we based our study on deterministic privacy preservation inspired by unobservable/indistinguishable output signal notions from control theory. The deterministic approach offers a stronger form of privacy, as it eliminates the possibility of even approximate estimations by adversaries, enhancing the security of distributed systems without introducing significant computational overhead. (f) Lastly, in collaboration with international partners, we explored resource-aware strategies for multi-agent deployment, addressing combinatorial optimization challenges in monitoring scenarios. Our statistical framework, based on Stein Variational Gradient Descent, identifies critical points of interest for agent allocation, optimizing coverage and resource utilization.

On the broader impact side, the research from this project has significantly advanced the theoretical foundations necessary for enabling distributed optimal decision-making in networked systems, with applications across various fields that have societal impact. This work has been instrumental in training the next generation of scientists and engineers at UC Irvine, including students from incoming undergraduates to Ph.D. candidates. These students have developed essential skills to tackle the complexities of the multifaceted systems and applications featured in the project. Key achievements include mentoring and supervising both undergraduate and graduate students, offering paid summer internships to high school students from underrepresented minority backgrounds, and conducting a quarterly 10-week freshman seminar series on optimal decision-making and motion planning for robots. Additionally, the research outcomes have been integrated into graduate courses taught by the PI at UCI. Graduate students involved in this project have successfully transitioned to industry careers at prominent companies such as Apple, FICO, and E-Ink. The project has also fostered a US-Indo international collaboration, applying the research results to practical applications in surface mining. This collaboration has enhanced the project's impact by addressing real-world challenges and facilitating knowledge exchange between international partners.The findings have been disseminated widely through conference and journal publications, the online availability of preprints and publications, and invited research talks at leading institutions.
